data: Embedded Multi-Core Systems for Mixed Criticality Applications in Dynamic and Changeable Real-Time Environments

Embedded systems are the key innovation driver to improve almost all mechatronic products with cheaper and even new functionalities. Furthermore, they strongly support today's information society as inter-system communication enabler.

Consequently boundaries of application domains are alleviated and ad-hoc connections and interoperability play an increasing role. At the same time, multi-core and many-core computing platforms are becoming available on the market and provide a breakthrough for system (and application) integration.

A major industrial challenge arises facing (cost) efficient integration of different applications with different levels of safety and security on a single computing platform in an open context.

The objective of the EMC² project (Embedded multi-core systems for mixed criticality applications in dynamic and changeable real-time environments) is to foster these changes through an innovative and sustainable service-oriented architecture approach for mixed criticality applications in dynamic and changeable real-time environments.

The EMC2 project focuses on the industrialization of European research outcomes and builds on the results of previous ARTEMIS, European and National projects. It provides the paradigm shift to a new and sustainable system architecture which is suitable to handle open dynamic systems.

EMC² is part of the European Embedded Systems industry strategy to maintain its leading edge position by providing solutions for:
. Dynamic Adaptability in Open Systems
. Utilization of expensive system features only as Service-on-Demand in order to reduce the overall system cost.
. Handling of mixed criticality applications under real-time conditions
. Scalability and utmost flexibility
. Full scale deployment and management of integrated tool chains, through the entire lifecycle

CRYSTAL aims at fostering Europe’s leading edge position in embedded systems engineering in particular regarding quality and cost effectiveness of safety-critical embedded systems and architecture platforms.

Its overall goal is to enable sustainable paths to speed up the maturation, integration, and cross-sectoral reusability of technological and methodological bricks of the factories for safety-critical embedded systems engineering in the areas of transportation (aerospace, automotive, and rail) and healthcare providing a critical mass of European technology providers.

CRYSTAL perfectly fits to other ARTEMIS projects, sharing the concept of a reference technology platform (RTP) as a consistent set of integration principles and seamless technology interoperability standards. Based on the methodologies of a service-oriented architecture and the results of previous projects CRYSTAL focuses on an industry-driven approach using cross-domain user stories, domain-specific use cases, public use cases, and technology bricks. This shall have a significant impact to strengthen European competitiveness regarding new markets and societal applications.

In building an overall interoperability domain “embedded systems”, CRYSTAL will contribute to establishing a standard for model-based systems engineering in a certification and safety context which is expected to have global impact.

By bringing together large enterprises and various industrial domains CRYSTAL will setup a sustainable innovation eco-system. By harmonizing the demands in the development of safety-relevant embedded systems including multi-viewpoint engineering and variability management across different industrial domains, CRYSTAL will achieve a strong acceptance from both vendors and the open-source community.

CRYSTAL will drive forward interoperability towards a “de facto” standard providing an interoperable European RTP.

REnaissance of Places with Innovative Citizenship and TEchnolgy

The objective of REPLICATE is to demonstrate Smart City technologies in energy, transport and ICT in districts in San Sebastia, Florence and Bristol addressing urban complexity and generate replication plans in other districts and in follower cities of Essen,
Nilufer and Lausanne.
Main challenges for cities are to increase the overall energy efficiency, to exploit better local resources in terms of energy
supply and demand side measures. For successful implementation of Smart City technologies two main elements are
considered:
- Cities are the customer: considering local specificities in integrated urban plans and the need to develop monitoring
systems to extract conclusions for replication.
- Solutions must be replicable, interoperable and scalable.
REPLICATE considers also the complexity of cities, the tangible benefits for citizens, the financial mechanisms and the new
business models. The 3 pillars implemented in the pilots with the engagement of citizens, private actors and authorities are:
- Low energy districts: cost-effective retrofitting, new constructive techniques with optimal energy behaviour and high
enthalpy RES in residential buildings. Include also efficient measures in public and residential buildings: ICT tools, PV,
shading or natural ventilation; district heating is demonstrated hybridising local biomass, recovered heat and natural gas.
- Integrated Infrastructure: deployment of ICT architecture, from internet of things to applications, to integrate the solutions in
different areas. Smart Grids on electricity distribution network to address the new challenges, connecting all users:
consumers, producers, aggregators and municipality. Intelligent lighting will allow automated regulation of the amount of light
and integration of IP services via PLC.
- Urban mobility: sustainable and smart urban bus service, electric urban bike transport, 3-wheeler delivery and transport
services, deployment of EV charging infrastructures and ICT tools.

As a busy and thriving Teaching School at the heart of Bristol's education landscape, Ashley Down Primary School is both challenged and excited by the increasing prominence of modern languages brought about by the 2014 curriculum. Our Modern Foreign Languages (MFL) mission is to create lifelong linguists. We feel that it is crucial that children enter the world equipped to communicate with their neighbours in the global forum. Whilst we are lucky to have many colleagues whose pedagogy and teaching skills are outstanding, we would like to build on this capacity by facilitating language learning of an equally high quality. This will be made possible through our project in partnership with Erasmus+. 

At the beginning of the project, the MFL Coordinator and two supporting colleagues, who have existing language skills, will participate in an initial immersion course where it will be possible not only to develop language teaching strategies, but also to spend some time strategically planning for the long term future of MFL in the school.  

When back in the UK, we will offer initial language training to all staff in the school setting so that they can establish or refresh basic language skills, before selecting five teachers who have shown particular aptitude, commitment and enthusiasm, to then participate in immersion courses. These staff will be from across the school so that their experiences will have a significant impact in all year groups. The residential training will give a focused time during which the provider will actively build on teachers' existing knowledge whilst advising on new and effective ways of bringing languages to life in the classroom. When teachers return from the immersion course, we will work with them to consider how their new practice can be best used in the context of their year group and more widely within the school strategy for languages.

The results of this project will be that all children across Ashley Down Primary School have an exciting, engaging and inspiring experience of language learning, which ignites a passion for languages and sets them up with the essential skills necessary to succeed as international citizens. In the longer term, it will mean that in our role as a Teaching School, we will be able to develop networks and training to support other Bristol schools in delivering high quality provision for language learning. Finally, it will of course also raise the profile of Erasmus+ as an invaluable partner in this vital work.

There are 4 teachers from different year groups within Filton Avenue Junior School, who want to train in language and methodology in order to embed Spanish into their school. Having at least one teacher per year group trained in Spanish, would enable the teaching to become more consistent throughout the school. The majority of the participants are new to the subject of Spanish and have little experience of teaching a language, and one participant is new to the role of MFL co-ordinator. This training will enable the participants to correctly follow the new National Curriculum, which is being launched this year. This training will also help to strengthen connections with national and international teachers, as well as creating permanent links with other European schools.

Having at least one person per year group trained to teach Spanish, the participants will be able to pass on their knowledge and skills to their year group colleagues, raise awareness about the importance of learning a language and strengthen attainment in Spanish. The participants will also impart their knowledge to all staff within the school through training sessions. This will help to increase cultural awareness, especially as we're in such a multicultural school where multiculturalism is valued and celebrated. The participants will introduce new teaching practices such as immersion, build cultural links and increase cultural awareness in staff, pupils and parents.

The participants will use this training as a springboard to launch the start of their journey into outstanding teaching in Spanish. This should enable their children to become confident and culturally aware individuals who are eager to learn more about foreign languages.
Sensibiliser les élèves de Bac Pro au marché européen de l'emploi grâce à un stage à l'étranger

Opening up to Europe has been regarded as a key area of development and identification for the subject area of Business and Administration taught in our school.
The school’s educational project is based around 3 key notions; self-belief, judgment and self-development. 
Going toward the other, sharing, building up, opening one’s mind, challenge, citizenship, relationships with others or growing up are keywords to illustrate these ideas and are fully compatible with our commitment to the development of a genuine European citizenship for our students . Our desire for this European dimension is part of this approach and fits in perfectly with this ambition. All the students who have completed their studies in Business and Administration in our school have been offered a trip abroad to a major European city at some point. Since 2004, the school has taught European Classes in English and Spanish on a voluntary basis with vocational subjects taught in English. The school has been involved in three European funded projects for nearly ten years : The Comenius, Leonardo and Erasmus Projects. A financial contribution has been granted by the school for each student having a work experience abroad. This 24-month mobility project is intended to students in our vocational school studying Administration, retail or Sales. The target group consists of students who were not allowed to attend  schools that teach academic subjects therefore seeing themselves as failing at school. Only a few of them came here because they wanted to , most of them being here because they have no other choice. The factors that could motivate the students  do not seem to appeal to them. This project will therefore  help  to remotivate them, to highlight their efforts and restore their self-confidence, to bring them back the pleasure of learning and doing their schoolwork regularly but also to make them aware of the European reality in all its diversity and richness and help them realize all the opportunities that Europe can offer. This  group of 8 boys and girls who are in the final year of a 3- year course  will go to Bristol for five weeks from mid-September to late October. Most of them who are 17 to 19 years old, belong to the European class designed to prepare them at school for this experience abroad including extra English lessons and extra lessons of vocational  subjects taught in English every week. In Bristol, they are placed in a host family on their own with no other guest. The mobility starts with a week  of intensive English Language courses organis ed by Académie Aquitaine,our intermediate partner for five years, Debbie being also the contact person and their tutor during the stay. Practising English and role-plays in working situations help them build  self-confidence before the training period starts the following week. This 4-week internship from late September to the mid-term holiday  is set,  according to the dates of the fifth training period done by all our students in their final year. On their flight to Bristol, the group is accompanied by their English teacher who takes this opportunity to meet the companies and shops’ managers again and remind them of the objectives to reach. At the end of the mobility, two teachers in Sales and Administration visit each workplace to fill in the official Assessment grid together with the student and the tutor and then fly back with them. This project also supports the attainment of training objectives in a  European context where company practices are different. These  assessments are taken into account in the vocational subjects of their final exam. This experience abroad is also tested during an oral exam which helps the beneficiary graduate with the European class option. The Europass portfolio and the Europro certificate are given to the students on a special European evening at the school. Through mobility the beneficiaries can certify the skills acquired and the competences developed such as integration, independence, open-mindedness, communication in a foreign language. We have been able to assess the progress made by the students in:
- the need for mobility as many plan to have other work experiences in Europe
- job and career opportunities on the European market
- their ability to adapt to a new context (personal or professional)
- European citizenship
- diversity of European culture and cultural understanding
- increased self-confidence and a greater maturity
- more educational opportunities at a higher level.
Today our school wants to play an important role in the European projects and disseminates the benefits. We have been contacted by The house of Europe in Bordeaux for a few projects and by the Specialist Schools and Academies Trust in London, the organisation which oversees specialist schools in England, to organise a vocational study visit for teachers to Bordeaux. The focus of the visit was to look at good practice in the areas of vocational education/bilingual teaching.
Applied Education for Refugee and Migrant Solidarity

Transformative Education is a non-profit organisation founded on the vision that education can serve a crucial role in supporting social responsibility and empowering social agency. Our work serves a broad range of civil society actors, including marginalised people. Currently our work contributes most directly to three areas: 1. Active citizenship, democracy & participation, 2. Social cohesion, equity and equality, 3. Migration and demographic change.

With our focus on education to strengthen civil society and active citizenship, we have found ourselves responding to increasingly prominent refugee and migrant issues. Consequently, for 2017-19 we have identified two key areas of strategic development:
1) Educating for Resilience in Refugee Solidarity Work
2) Transversality and Strategising for Inclusion.

1) Under the first we want to be better equipped to support adult educators and other organisers and volunteers engaged in refugee solidarity work. We want our own trainers to gain key skills and competences to address new challenges. We also seek to develop our capacity to train others (including educators) in specific topics we have identified as crucial to supporting that work. 

Therefore, we aim for this project to enable staff to acquire skills to work with: burnout; trauma and post-traumatic stress; knowledge and skills from the work of HRDs on security that is transferable; all in support of educators and volunteers working on refugee solidarity.

2) We recognise that educational work engaging migrants can be greatly enhanced by tools and approaches developed in ‘Anti-Oppression Pedagogy’. Also, that contributing as adult educators to addressing the many social issues related to refugees and migrants requires strong transversal and civil society cooperation across sectors and movements. Improved strategic thinking and planning is crucial to meet these important challenges. 

Therefore, under the heading of ‘Transversality and Strategising for Inclusion’, we are planning this project to meet the need to: deepen our understanding of anti-oppression pedagogies and especially more effective ways to help adult educators work with diversity and the challenges of ‘othering’ as it manifests in themselves and amongst their learners; and deepen our understanding of transversal cooperation within civil society and how that can inform the strategic development of our educational work.
The project also has aims at the European level, which include: Connecting with organisations and trainers who can support us to meet the above objectives; extending the provision of our educational work and strengthening our connections with networks developing similar work; to share best practice and innovation to increase sectoral capacity.

During 2017 and 2018, 20 members of staff (comprised of a balance of more and less experienced personnel) will attend courses focused on the themes identified in our strategic plan. The learning will be integrated into the work of Transformative Education; shared across the sector; form the basis of developing and delivering new and innovative curricula that will support educators, professionals and volunteers engaged in refugee and migrant solidarity work, as well as refugees and migrants directly.

Additionally, staff will see: Increased foreign language competence; Increased opportunities to network and forge connections with European educators and organisations; increased inter-cultural experience; increased sharing and learning of best practice; and new and enhanced skills that will improve their professional development and ability to gain and secure paid employment.

 We have chosen the Ulex Project (run by Col·lectiu Eco-Actiu) as the training provider because it is possibly unique in Europe as a residential educational centre focused on providing high quality training for civil society organisations to support ‘social movement impact and resilience’. Their methodological approach is called ‘Integral Training’, it is participatory, applied and learner-centred. All aspects we value highly in adult education. They complement their in-house facilitation team by bringing together talented international trainers. Together with their efforts to pilot and develop new curricula, this offers access to some of the best and most innovative training in the field.

The longer term benefits will include: Increased provision of refugee solidarity education; greater well-being and professional longevity for educators doing this work; enhanced social integration and inclusion; increased excellence in the design and delivery of new and innovative curricula; more effective strategic alliances and cooperation between civil society entities (including those involved in informal adult education); increased trans-European cooperation between educators; and an increase in a sense of a positive and progressive European identity.
Building Capacity for Migrant and Minority Led Education

Transformative Education is a non-profit organisation that seeks to support the empowerment of individuals and communities to contribute to an increase in social justice, ecological intelligence and the flourishing of people and the ecosystems they live within.
Between 2015 and 2017 we developed important connections with a number of European refugee solidarity initiatives. During 2016 we identified two related areas of strategic development under the headings ‘Transversality and Strategising for Inclusion’ and ‘Educating for Resilience in Refugee Solidarity Work’.

In part through an Erasmus Plus project that began in 2017 (and comes to an end in August 2018), we took initiatives to better equip educators and other organisers working in that field. This led us identify the additional need to build capacity for migrant led education and an increase in the capacity amongst trainers and educators from a migrant background and ethnic minorities, together with two additional areas of development. 

On this basis we have identified two further areas of strategic development for 2018-19. These fall under the headings of:

1) Building Capacity for Migrant and Minority Led Education
2) Applying Innovative Pedagogies in Migrant Education

1) Under the heading of Building Capacity for Migrant and Minority Led Education , we want to to increase the availability and capacity of trainers from a migrant background and ethnic minorities able to offer leadership development and empowering education to learners from similar backgrounds.

Building leadership from within minority communities has long been recognised as a key step towards social empowerment, integration and self-advocacy. Such leadership is crucial in situations that often render minorities invisible and discriminate against them. Educators themselves can often fulfil leadership roles through supporting, mentoring and nurturing the development of others. Equipped with methodologies which aim to empower learners – such as popular, participatory, and learner centred educational approaches – educators can strengthen the process of ‘transformation from below’, where marginalised people can build confidence and ability to challenge discrimination, assert their rights, and transform social relationships for the better. 

We aim for this project to enable staff to acquire and improve skills to provide leadership development training to migrant and minority groups; deepen their knowledge of participatory and popular education methods appropriate to these learner groups; increase their competence to engage diverse learners; and to develop greater confidence in their own leadership qualities and embody these as educators.

2) Under the heading of Applying Innovative Pedagogies in Migrant Education, we want staff to acquire and improve skills to use tools and techniques developed in Nature Connection Education and Mindfulness-based approaches to be applied in educational initiatives to support resilience and wellbeing for migrants, asylum seekers and undocumented people. This will increase staff competence to develop and deliver new curricula that integrate these newly acquired skills.

Together the planned activities will result in an increase in the availability of education for migrants, refugees and learners from other minority backgrounds. We hope it will lead to migrant and minority led education that increases leadership capacity within these same groups and communities. Such leadership skills will support these groups to increase their own capacity to advocate for social inclusion and integration, improving the material conditions of their lives and social well-being. We want to support educators from these minority backgrounds themselves to provide examples of embodied leadership and able to transform the conditions that often render minorities invisible and facing discrimination. All in all, this will lead to the empowerment of the social process of ‘transformation from below’.

Between September 2018 and September 2019, we will send 12 staff, themselves from migrant and minority backgrounds, on two tailored course. A further four staff will attend two programmed courses. These mobilities will be designed and delivered by our partner, the Ulex Project, who we have chosen because of a) the proven high quality of their training work, and b) the possibility of working closely with them to tailor these trainings to our specific needs. 

Staff will benefit from increased foreign language competence; opportunities to forge connections with European educators; and enhanced skills that will improve their professional development and ability to gain and secure paid employment.

At a European level the project will strengthen networking between organisations and trainers who share commitments to develop empowering educational opportunities that support social inclusion and provision of high quality education to disadvantaged learners.
